title: Curtis Stone wants George Calombaris to open up restaurants in the US
text:
He's the Australian Michelin-star chef with two successful restaurants in Los Angeles.

And on Tuesday, Curtis Stone revealed he is also encouraging George Calombaris to set up shop in the US.

Speaking to The Herald Sun, the 43-year-old chef said it is 'absolutely' time for the public to forgive the axed MasterChef judge after his $8 million underpayment saga.

'I'm convincing him to come to LA!' Curtis Stone wants George Calombaris to open up restaurants in the US - as he urges the public to forgive the axed Masterchef judge. Left to right: Gary Mehigan, Curtis Stone, George Calombaris and Matt Preston

'I just had dinner there (George's restaurant) while I was in Melbourne last week and it's so good, I'm trying to convince him to come to LA and open one there,' Curtis said.

Curtis had dined at George's Greek restaurant Hellenic Republic in Brighton, but the former Masterchef judge owns 19 more establishments.

'It's only pretty recent that broadly we've celebrated Greek cuisine and George has been clearly at the forefront of that,' Curtis said.

Complement: 'It's only pretty recent that broadly we've celebrated Greek cuisine and George has been clearly at the forefront of that,' Curtis said of George's impact

Despite the controversy surrounding George, it seems Curtis is keen to back his fellow celebrity chef friend.

Curtis has appeared as a guest judge in five seasons of MasterChef, most recently season 11, which was George's final series.

The original trio of George, Matt Preston and Gary Mehigan reportedly walked away from the program after Channel Ten refused to give them a pay rise in July.

At the time, George was also facing controversy for underpaying his restaurant staff by nearly $8 million between 2011 and 2017.

Buddies! Curtis has appeared as a guest judge in five seasons of MasterChef, most recently season 11, which was George's final series

In July, the embattled chef was hit with a $200,000 fine, with many viewers calling for him to be dumped from the show.

In a statement - which avoided mentioning Calombaris' scandal - Ten's CEO Paul Anderson claimed the decision to axe the three judges came after months of failed negotiations.

Mr Anderson said: 'Despite months of negotiations, Ten has not been able to reach a commercial agreement that was satisfactory to Matt, Gary and George.

'We would like to thank Gary, George and Matt for their contribution over the past 11 years.'
